moves.1. d4: Queen's pawn game, white's d-pawn occupies the center
moves.1... d5: Black establishes a pawn in the center and controlls white's c4 and e4 squares
moves.2. c4: Queen's gambit, white threatens to exchange a wining pawn and dominate the center with e4.
moves.2... e6: black declines the gambit and releases Black's dark squared bishop
moves.3. Nc3 c6: now black converted the game into delayed slav defence
moves.8. O-O b5 9. cxd5 cxd5 10. e4: forcing the black's d-pawn and trying to devolp white's center with Night and Bishop.
moves.13. Bg5 f6 14. Bd2 f5: black unable to do O-O.so he want's to block b1-h1 diagonal for white's Bishop.
moves.15. Bxf5: this is the turning point in this game, trying to open e' file for Rook. Its stronger than defending the Bishop from e4 to d3 or Bc6.
moves.16. Rfe1+: after this, Black's king trying to escape, but not longer.
moves.16... Kf8 17. Ba5: a little plan to distroy black's both king and queen sides
moves.17... Bc7: Rc7 better. But can't hold too longer.17...Rc7 Bxc7 18. Rac1 Bxh2+ 19. Kxh2 Bb7 20. Qxf5+ Nf6 21. Qc5+ Kf7 22. Qc7+ Qxc7+ 23. Rx27+ wining a bishop.
moves.18. Bb4+ Kf7 19. Re7+ Qxe7: 19. Kg6 not good 20. Nh4+ Nh6 21. Nxf5+ Kg5 22. Rxg7+ Kf6 23. Qc6+ Bd6 24. Qxd6+ Kxf5 25. Qd5+ Ne5 26. Qxe5#
moves.20. Bxe7: alternave can be tried 20. Qb3+ Kg6 21. Bxe7 h6 22. Qe6+ Nf6 23. Nh4+ Kh7 24. Qf7 Ng4 25. g3 Rg8 26. h3 f4 27. hxg4 fxg3 28. Bxf6 gxf2+ 29. Kf1 Bf4 30. Qxa7 Be3 31. Qe7 Be6 32. Qxe6 gxf6 33. Qxe3 Rxg4 34. Rc1 Rg1+ 35. Kxf2 Rg4 36. Rc7+ Rg7 37. Qe4+ f5 38. Qxf5 Kh8 39. Qf8+ Rg8 40. Ng6#
